This is capitalized at the occurrences I found, but with no explanation. It would seem that 'mono-dialectal is perfectly sufficient, isn't it? In case nonstandard use (capitals) is necessary, explanation is required.

The hyphen used here is longer than that used at other occurrences of the same phrase. Better to use the same one throughout. Recommended: the simple, plain hyphen, '-'

P is explained as meaning Probability, and all is for the best. But then 'EC' and 'PC', which appear in the same equation, are not explained here. This comes as a disappointment. The text is intelligible nonetheless, but since the variables (acronyms) are taken up again in the next paragraph it would really seem useful to recall here what they stand for.

I thought it should be 'see §3.4.3.2' and so forth (throughout the volume). Looks like this is a 'hard-encoded' reference instead of a dynamic link. See 3rd line of §(!)4.1.1, where there is a well-encoded link: 'see §3.3.2')

column7: Explanation of variable coming too late
column8: Aha, so here we go! PC = possible combinations.  Should really be explained (again) at 1st occurrence in this chapter.

The acronym 'PVR' is hard (for me): never saw it before. Providing a description that does not match the feature tag really seems asking a lot of the reader ;-) If you call it *postvocalic <r>*, then so be it called at the (few) places where it's explained...?

At another place it's called 'post vocalic <r>'. To me, 'postvocalic' (no space, no hyphen) would look fine; at any rate, please harmonize. Capitalization in the description does not need necessary: even if the acronym (label) is PVC, the description could be simple 'postvocalic <r>' or 'postvocalic /r/'. (Choice between <r> and /r/: the latter seems better: standard in phonology, so maybe stick to that unless there are specific reasons to do otherwise.)
See comment below on main text:  - is the hyphen necessary? - wouldn't /r/ be more standard? Any specific reason to use <r> rather than /r/?
See previous comments: 'post' seems better than 'Post', and the hyphen may be unnecessary (at any rate, harmonization would seem better).
(see previous comments: sometimes post vocalic, sometimes post--vocalic... 'postvocalic' may be best; at any rate, harmonize)
(if the aim is 'standard' English, of course; note that I'm not a native speaker)
(as it comes again at the end of the phrase)
(or add another one after 'in my mind,')
